name: CCPA/CPRA
description: The California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), as amended by the California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA), grants California consumers comprehensive rights over their personal information and imposes obligations on businesses that collect, use, share, or sell personal information. Enforced by the California Privacy Protection Agency (CPPA), the law applies to for-profit businesses meeting specific revenue, data volume, or data sale thresholds, and establishes requirements for transparency, data minimization, purpose limitation, and the protection of sensitive personal information.

domains.name: Consumer Rights
domains.description: Core consumer rights under CCPA/CPRA including the right to know, delete, correct, opt-out of sale/sharing, limit use of sensitive personal information, and non-discrimination for exercising privacy rights.

controls.title: Right to Know / Access
controls.description: Consumers have the right to request that a business disclose the categories and specific pieces of personal information it has collected about them, the categories of sources, the business or commercial purpose for collecting or selling the information, and the categories of third parties with whom the business shares personal information. Businesses must respond within 45 days.
typical_evidence: Consumer request intake and verification procedures
Request fulfillment workflow documentation
Response templates for access requests
Request tracking log with timestamps and response times
Identity verification procedures for consumer requests

controls.title: Right to Delete
controls.description: Consumers have the right to request the deletion of personal information that a business has collected from them. Businesses must delete the information and direct any service providers or contractors to also delete the information, subject to specific exceptions such as completing transactions, detecting security incidents, or complying with legal obligations.
typical_evidence: Deletion request handling procedures
Technical deletion capability documentation across all systems
Service provider deletion notification process
Deletion verification and confirmation records
Exception criteria documentation for denied deletion requests

controls.title: Right to Opt-Out of Sale or Sharing
controls.description: Consumers have the right to direct a business that sells or shares their personal information to stop selling or sharing that information. Businesses must provide a clear and conspicuous 'Do Not Sell or Share My Personal Information' link on their website and honor Global Privacy Control (GPC) signals.
typical_evidence: Do Not Sell or Share link implementation evidence
Global Privacy Control (GPC) signal detection and honoring mechanism
Opt-out request processing procedures
Downstream notification to third parties upon opt-out
Opt-out preference management system documentation

controls.title: Right to Correct
controls.description: Consumers have the right to request that a business correct inaccurate personal information that it maintains about them. Businesses must use commercially reasonable efforts to correct the information as directed by the consumer and instruct service providers and contractors to make the same correction.
typical_evidence: Correction request intake and handling procedures
Data accuracy verification workflow
Service provider correction notification process
Correction request tracking log
Documentation of commercially reasonable efforts standard

controls.title: Right to Limit Use of Sensitive Personal Information
controls.description: Consumers have the right to direct a business to limit its use and disclosure of sensitive personal information to that which is necessary to perform the services or provide the goods reasonably expected by an average consumer. Businesses must provide a 'Limit the Use of My Sensitive Personal Information' link.
typical_evidence: Limit the Use of My Sensitive Personal Information link implementation
Sensitive personal information use limitation procedures
Technical controls restricting SPI processing to permitted purposes
Consumer preference management for SPI limitations
Service provider notification of SPI use limitations

controls.title: Right to Non-Discrimination
controls.description: Businesses shall not discriminate against a consumer because the consumer exercised any of their CCPA rights. Discrimination includes denying goods or services, charging different prices or rates, providing a different level or quality of goods or services, or suggesting that the consumer will receive a different price or quality. Financial incentive programs are permitted with proper notice and opt-in consent.
typical_evidence: Non-discrimination policy documentation
Pricing and service level consistency monitoring
Financial incentive program disclosures and opt-in records
Training materials on non-discriminatory practices
Consumer complaint tracking related to discrimination

domains.name: Business Obligations
domains.description: Requirements for businesses regarding notice at collection, data minimization, purpose limitation, and data retention, ensuring transparent and responsible handling of consumer personal information.

controls.title: Notice at Collection
controls.description: Businesses must inform consumers at or before the point of collection about the categories of personal information to be collected, the purposes for which the information will be used, whether the information is sold or shared, and the length of time the business intends to retain each category of personal information.
typical_evidence: Privacy notice at point of collection (website, app, in-store)
Notice content review against CCPA requirements checklist
Notice versioning and update history
Evidence of notice accessibility across all collection channels
Retention period disclosures per category of personal information

controls.title: Privacy Policy
controls.description: Businesses must maintain a comprehensive privacy policy that is updated at least every 12 months. The privacy policy must include a description of consumer rights, categories of personal information collected, sold, or shared in the preceding 12 months, and instructions for submitting verifiable consumer requests.
typical_evidence: Current privacy policy document
Annual privacy policy review and update records
Privacy policy change log with effective dates
Metrics disclosure on categories of information collected, sold, and shared
Consumer request submission method documentation

controls.title: Data Minimization
controls.description: A business's collection, use, retention, and sharing of a consumer's personal information shall be reasonably necessary and proportionate to achieve the purposes for which the personal information was collected or processed. Businesses must not collect more personal information than is needed for the disclosed purpose.
typical_evidence: Data minimization assessment documentation
Data collection justification for each category of personal information
Periodic reviews of data collection practices
System configuration evidence showing minimal data fields
Data mapping showing necessity for each data element

controls.title: Purpose Limitation
controls.description: Businesses shall not collect or use personal information for additional purposes that are incompatible with the disclosed purpose for which the personal information was collected without providing the consumer with notice. Secondary uses must be compatible with the context in which the information was originally collected.
typical_evidence: Purpose specification documentation per data collection activity
Compatibility assessment records for secondary uses
Consumer notification procedures for new purposes
Processing activity register linking data to declared purposes
Controls preventing unauthorized purpose expansion

controls.title: Data Retention Limitations
controls.description: A business shall not retain a consumer's personal information for each disclosed purpose for which the personal information was collected for longer than is reasonably necessary for that disclosed purpose. Businesses must disclose retention periods or the criteria used to determine retention periods.
typical_evidence: Data retention policy with defined periods per category
Retention schedule mapped to collection purposes
Automated data purge and archival configurations
Retention period justification documentation
Periodic retention compliance audit records

domains.name: Data Protection
domains.description: Security safeguards, breach notification requirements, and risk assessment obligations to protect consumer personal information from unauthorized access, destruction, use, modification, or disclosure.

controls.title: Reasonable Security Measures
controls.description: Businesses that own, license, or maintain personal information about California residents shall implement and maintain reasonable security procedures and practices appropriate to the nature of the information, to protect the personal information from unauthorized or illegal access, destruction, use, modification, or disclosure. Failure to do so may result in a private right of action under the CCPA data breach provisions.
typical_evidence: Information security policy and program documentation
Security controls inventory mapped to CIS or NIST frameworks
Encryption standards for data at rest and in transit
Access control policies and implementation evidence
Penetration testing and vulnerability assessment reports

controls.title: Data Breach Notification
controls.description: Any business that owns or licenses computerized personal information shall disclose a breach of the security of the system to any California resident whose unencrypted personal information was, or is reasonably believed to have been, acquired by an unauthorized person. Notification must be made in the most expedient time possible and without unreasonable delay.
typical_evidence: Data breach response plan and playbook
Breach detection and escalation procedures
Consumer breach notification templates
Attorney General notification procedures and records
Breach impact assessment methodology documentation

controls.title: Cybersecurity Audit
controls.description: Businesses whose processing of consumers' personal information presents significant risk to consumers' privacy or security shall perform an annual cybersecurity audit. The audit must be thorough and independent, and the scope must be defined by CPPA regulations.
typical_evidence: Annual cybersecurity audit report
Audit scope and methodology documentation
Independent auditor qualifications and engagement letter
Remediation plans for audit findings
Board or management review of audit results

controls.title: Risk Assessment for Processing
controls.description: Businesses whose processing of consumers' personal information presents significant risk to consumers' privacy or security shall submit to the CPPA on a regular basis a risk assessment with respect to their processing of personal information. The assessment must weigh the benefits of the processing against the potential risks to consumer rights.
typical_evidence: Risk assessment reports submitted to CPPA
Processing risk identification and evaluation methodology
Risk-benefit analysis documentation
Mitigation measures for identified risks
Risk assessment update and review schedule

domains.name: Sensitive Personal Information
domains.description: Special requirements for the collection, use, and protection of sensitive personal information including Social Security numbers, financial information, precise geolocation, racial or ethnic origin, religious beliefs, genetic data, biometric data, health information, sex life or sexual orientation, and contents of communications.

controls.title: Sensitive Personal Information Identification and Classification
controls.description: Businesses must identify and classify sensitive personal information (SPI) they collect and process, including government identifiers, financial account information, precise geolocation, racial or ethnic origin, religious beliefs, contents of mail/email/text, genetic data, biometric information, health data, and sex life or sexual orientation data.
typical_evidence: Sensitive personal information data inventory
Data classification scheme including SPI categories
Data mapping showing SPI flows across systems
SPI identification procedures for new data collection activities
Technical tagging or labeling of SPI in systems

controls.title: Consent for Sensitive Personal Information Use
controls.description: Where a consumer has exercised their right to limit, a business may only use or disclose sensitive personal information for purposes authorized by the CCPA regulations, such as performing services expected by the consumer, ensuring security, and verifying quality. Additional uses beyond these permitted purposes require explicit consumer consent.
typical_evidence: Consent collection mechanism for SPI processing beyond permitted purposes
Consent records and management system documentation
Permitted purpose justification for each SPI use
Consumer-facing disclosures about SPI use and limitation rights
Technical controls enforcing SPI processing restrictions

controls.title: Enhanced Protections for Sensitive Personal Information
controls.description: Businesses must implement enhanced safeguards for sensitive personal information including additional access controls, encryption, monitoring, and retention limitations. SPI requires a higher standard of protection commensurate with the increased risks to consumers if the information is compromised.
typical_evidence: Enhanced access controls for SPI data stores
Encryption standards specific to SPI at rest and in transit
SPI-specific audit logging and monitoring procedures
Shorter retention periods for SPI categories
SPI handling training and awareness materials

domains.name: Service Provider and Third Party Requirements
domains.description: Contractual, due diligence, and oversight requirements for service providers, contractors, and third parties that receive, process, or access consumer personal information on behalf of or from the business.

controls.title: Service Provider and Contractor Agreements
controls.description: Businesses must enter into written contracts with service providers and contractors that prohibit selling or sharing personal information received, retaining or using the information for purposes other than those specified in the contract, and combining the information with personal information from other sources. Contracts must require compliance with CCPA obligations.
typical_evidence: Service provider and contractor agreement templates with CCPA clauses
Executed contracts with required CCPA provisions
Contract review checklist for CCPA compliance
Contract inventory tracking CCPA-compliant agreements
Legal review records for service provider and contractor terms

controls.title: Third Party Due Diligence
controls.description: Businesses must exercise due diligence to ensure that third parties, service providers, and contractors are capable of complying with CCPA requirements. Businesses must determine whether the entity receiving personal information is acting as a service provider, contractor, or third party, and apply appropriate contractual and oversight mechanisms.
typical_evidence: Third party privacy and security assessment questionnaires
Due diligence evaluation reports for data recipients
Third party classification records (service provider, contractor, or third party)
Risk-based tiering of third party relationships
Due diligence renewal schedule and completion records

controls.title: Third Party Monitoring and Audit Rights
controls.description: Businesses must monitor service providers' and contractors' compliance with contractual CCPA obligations and exercise audit rights when warranted. If a business becomes aware that a service provider or contractor is using personal information in violation of the contract, the business must take reasonable steps to stop and remediate the unauthorized use.
typical_evidence: Service provider compliance monitoring procedures
Audit right clauses in contracts and audit schedules
Service provider audit reports or certification reviews
Remediation records for identified non-compliance
Incident escalation procedures for third party CCPA violations

controls.title: Consumer Request Fulfillment Across the Supply Chain
controls.description: When a business receives a verifiable consumer request, it must notify all service providers, contractors, and third parties that have received the consumer's personal information to comply with the request (e.g., deletion, correction, opt-out). Businesses must maintain processes to propagate consumer requests throughout the data supply chain.
typical_evidence: Consumer request propagation procedures to downstream entities
Service provider and third party notification records
Downstream compliance confirmation tracking
Automated mechanisms for request propagation where applicable
SLA documentation for third party response to consumer requests

domains.name: Privacy Program Management
domains.description: Governance, accountability, and operational requirements for establishing and maintaining a privacy program that ensures ongoing compliance with CCPA/CPRA, including data protection impact assessments, training, record keeping, and automated decision-making transparency.

controls.title: Privacy Program Governance
controls.description: Businesses must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program with assigned accountability, adequate resources, and executive oversight. The program must include policies, procedures, and controls to ensure compliance with all CCPA/CPRA requirements, including designated personnel responsible for privacy compliance.
typical_evidence: Privacy program charter and governance framework
Designated privacy officer or responsible person appointment
Privacy program budget and resource allocation records
Executive and board reporting on privacy compliance
Privacy program maturity assessment documentation

controls.title: Privacy Training and Awareness
controls.description: All individuals responsible for handling consumer inquiries about the business's privacy practices or the business's compliance with CCPA must be informed of the requirements of the CCPA and how to direct consumers to exercise their rights. Businesses should implement regular privacy training for all personnel who handle personal information.
typical_evidence: CCPA-specific training curriculum and materials
Training completion records for all relevant personnel
Annual training refresher schedule and attendance logs
Consumer-facing staff training on rights request handling
Training effectiveness assessment and knowledge verification

controls.title: Record Keeping and Request Metrics
controls.description: Businesses that handle 10 million or more consumers' personal information annually must compile metrics on consumer requests received, complied with, denied, and the median response time. These metrics must be disclosed in the privacy policy or posted on the business's website. All businesses must maintain records of consumer requests and responses for at least 24 months.
typical_evidence: Consumer request tracking system and database
Quarterly and annual request metrics reports
Metrics disclosures in privacy policy or on website
24-month record retention for consumer request records
Request categorization and outcome classification records

controls.title: Data Protection Impact Assessment
controls.description: Businesses whose processing presents significant risk to consumers' privacy or security must conduct regular data protection impact assessments that identify and weigh the benefits of the processing against the potential risks to consumer rights. Assessments must be submitted to the CPPA and updated when processing activities materially change.
typical_evidence: DPIA methodology and assessment templates
Completed DPIA reports for high-risk processing activities
Risk-benefit analysis documentation
CPPA submission records for completed DPIAs
DPIA update triggers and review schedule

controls.title: Automated Decision-Making Transparency
controls.description: Businesses that use automated decision-making technology, including profiling, that produces legal or similarly significant effects on consumers must provide meaningful information about the logic involved, the significance, and the envisaged consequences of such processing. Consumers have the right to opt out of automated decision-making and to access information about how such decisions are made.
typical_evidence: Inventory of automated decision-making systems and profiling activities
Logic and methodology documentation for automated decisions
Consumer-facing disclosures about automated decision-making
Opt-out mechanism for automated decision-making
Human review procedures for consequential automated decisions

controls.title: Children's Personal Information Protections
controls.description: Businesses must obtain opt-in consent before selling or sharing the personal information of consumers under 16 years of age. For consumers under 13, the consent must come from the consumer's parent or guardian. Businesses with actual knowledge that they collect personal information from children must implement additional safeguards and verification procedures.
typical_evidence: Age verification procedures and technical implementation
Parental and guardian consent collection mechanisms for under-13 consumers
Opt-in consent workflows for consumers aged 13-15
Records of consent for minors' personal information processing
Enhanced privacy protections for children's data
